image.altText: Huge plumes of smoke from a scrub fire.

props.synopsis: Dozens of firefighters have spent all night at the scene of a scrub fire south east of Adelaide.

title.children: Busy night for firefighters as blaze burns in SA's south east

image.altText: A vehicle on the salt surface of South Australia's Lake Gairdner.

props.synopsis: Since 1990, a growing band of enthusiasts has been annually returning to Lake Gairdner — and this year their number included a 96-year-old who reached 97mph on the smooth and dry salt surface.

title.children: Outback salt lake flooded with speedsters seeking the perfect run

image.altText: A young man with a cap and light brown shirt standing onboard of a paddle steamer.

props.synopsis: While some 22-year-olds are saving for a house, an Adelaide man has purchased a piece of paddle-steaming history, hoping to save money on housing as well as satisfying his inland shipping history interests.

title.children: Historic paddleboat becomes cheap alternative to 'expensive' housing for shipwright

image.altText: A truck next to a power pole.

props.synopsis: The transmission company at the centre of Friday's major power outage in South Australia has "serious questions" to answer about whether the situation could have been prevented, the state government says.

title.children: Electricity company told to 'explain themselves' over peninsula blackout

image.altText: Dr Megan Brooks has a hand raised as she speaks during a parliamentary committee

props.synopsis: Speaking under parliamentary privilege, the testimony of emergency physician Megan Brooks was a rare public window into a health system under constant pressure, writes Leah MacLennan.

title.children: Doctor initially silenced at inquest gives inside look at ramping crisis

image.altText: An Aboriginal woman standing among a group of colourful graves with mosaic headstones.

props.synopsis: An Aboriginal community in far west New South Wales works through grief for lost loved ones with a hands-on project using the art of mosaic.

title.children: 'Represents how broken you feel': Mosaic headstones help people with grief

image.altText: Image of three dogs on a rock

props.synopsis: A team on Kangaroo Island is making a final push to eradicate feral cats using specially trained hounds and high-tech traps.

title.children: How three dogs could help Kangaroo Island eliminate feral cats

image.altText: Trees along a riverbank.

props.synopsis: As one end of the country contends with the fallout from ex-Tropical Cyclone Alfred, another part of Australia is battling the opposite conditions. Hopes that water will make its way south are evaporating fast, with experts saying conditions are too dry.

title.children: Little hope for ex-cyclone flows in NSW, Victoria and SA, experts warn

image.altText: A woman wearing a green shirt and apron sniffs a small blue container

props.synopsis: Olive oil producers and judges want Australians to get more familiar with the different flavours of the pantry staple.

title.children: Tasting room helps consumers detect different flavours in olive oil

image.altText: Football players clash on field.

props.synopsis: State football leagues like the SANFL, which is already enjoying growing audiences, have a chance to draw in new audiences by broadcasting free-to-air games on Saturday now that the AFL is not.

title.children: State leagues to fill gap as AFL cuts free Saturday footy TV broadcasts

image.altText: Two Indigenous women smile at the camera in a composite image that includes a black and white photo and red desert.

props.synopsis: It has been more than 40 years since the Pintupi Nine made contact with the modern world. Much has changed in their lives, but their country has never stopped calling them home.

title.children: For years, these sisters didn't know white people existed

image.altText: A cargo ship at sea with many colourful containers.

props.synopsis: If the events of the past few weeks have proven anything, it is that free trade agreements are worthless, at least when it comes to trade.

title.children: How America ripped off Australia with 'free trade'

image.altText: A woman with dark hair smiles for a portrait.

props.synopsis: An ABC investigation reveals police may have failed to identify another victim of convicted healthcare killer Garry Davis, who was found guilty of murdering two nursing home residents and attempting to kill a third by injecting them with lethal doses of insulin.

title.children: Retired detective queries police investigation of aged care killer

image.altText: Burned out and dizzy female person with hands covering face. Vector illustration.

props.synopsis: Health anxiety, which is characterised by excessive worrying about illness, is a real condition that can — somewhat ironically — make you sick. But it's also treatable.

title.children: 'It's debilitating': How Dr Google can make you sick

image.altText: A man in glasses and a south african coloured scarf

props.synopsis: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio says South Africa's ambassador to the United States "is no longer welcome" in the country, accusing him of hating US President Donald Trump.

title.children: South African ambassador 'no longer welcome', US Secretary of State says

image.altText: A woman with long blonde hair

props.synopsis: Wendy Williams tossed a note pleading for help from the window of the assisted care facility where she's been living for three years, reopening a debate about legal guardianships in the US.

title.children: A beloved US talk show host says she's imprisoned in a care facility

image.altText: A group of Yemeni men and boys hold up rifles in protest as they shout slogans.

props.synopsis: The strikes are the first to hit Yemen since the Gaza ceasefire deal took effect in January, and signal a more aggressive approach from the US, which has previously limited its actions to degrading the Houthis' ability to carry out missile and drone attacks.

title.children: Trump orders strikes on Yemen's capital over attacks on Red Sea shipping

image.altText: A blue F3 car is smashes, missing wheels, after crashing into the wall

props.synopsis: McLaren is starting at the front, Lewis Hamilton makes his Ferrari debut, and rain is forecast for the Australian Grand Prix. Follow live.

title.children: Rain forecast for F1 start, wet weather causing chaos at Albert Park

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Get to know Australian F1 driver Jack Doohan
Supercars race will not resume. No points to be awarded
F3 races ends with a red flag as rain causes chaos

image.altText: Oscar Piastri and Lando Norris stand opposite each other after a qualifying session

props.synopsis: McLaren is starting the 2025 season with a front-row lockout of the Australian Grand Prix, with both drivers eyeing victory and the early championship lead.

title.children: Piastri and Norris free to race as McLaren prepares for season-long battle

image.altText: A white man with cropped hair and glasses wearing a blue shirt stands with his hands in his pockets against a wall

props.synopsis: Robert Lukins' third novel is a Succession-like saga set in a wealthy enclave in Connecticut in the 1990s.

title.children: Author admits 'monstrous' characters are drawn from himself

props.synopsis: Around the clock coverage of news events as they break at home and abroad.

title.children: ABC News Channel live

image.altText: A man with strawberry blonde hair looks at the camera with a serious face.

props.synopsis: Two years ago, former NBL player Harry Froling was laying in a hospital bed fighting for his life. Now he's set on coming back better than ever.

title.children: After a sickening one-punch attack, Harry Froling was told he'd never play basketball again

image.altText: A Culex quinquefasciatus mosquito

props.synopsis: Health officials have warned people in recently flooded areas of the country to protect against mosquito-borne diseases after a new case of Japanese encephalitis was detected in NSW.

title.children: Why Japanese encephalitis cases are rising in Australia

image.altText: A small boat heads towards a turbine in the ocean.

props.synopsis: Offshore wind faces community and political opposition as well support for its promise of ample renewable energy and while some claims can be ruled out, experts say other concerns are valid.

title.children: Do offshore turbines kill whales? Wind farm facts, fiction and unknowns

image.altText: Two men dressed in hickory golf attire.

props.synopsis: Hickory golf is a game in which attention to your dress attire is as important as the shots you fire.

title.children: Golfers 'hooked' on hickories keep antique wooden clubs in full swing

image.altText: Swiatek

props.synopsis: Iga Swiatek loses her cool and smashes a ball back at a ball kid in an ugly incident during the Indian Wells Open semifinal.

title.children: Swiatek booed after ugly incident with ball kid at Indian Wells

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair wears a white cap and shirt and rests her chin on her hand, looking off camera in a park, smiling.

props.synopsis: As running clubs soared in popularity after the pandemic, Ash, a non-runner, struggled to find her own community — so she started a walking club.

title.children: After running clubs exploded, Ash started a walking club

image.altText: Starbucks has said it plans to appeal the verdict.

props.synopsis: The negligence lawsuit blamed the man's injuries on Starbucks, saying that an employee didn't wedge the scalding-hot tea firmly enough into a take-out tray.

title.children: US delivery driver wins $79 million in lawsuit over burns from Starbucks tea

image.altText: An Aboriginal young woman, with black hair and a red stripe, holding a paint brush while dying someone's hair.

props.synopsis: Whether it's a fade, mullet or colours, a mobile salon set up in a shipping container out bush is giving Indigenous students access to haircuts and the opportunity to learn the trade.

title.children: 'People are thrilled': New remote salon ends hours-long trip for a cut

image.altText: a man, woman and child pose out the front of a pub

props.synopsis: In the southern Queensland town of Laidley, floodwaters come and go but the people stay.

title.children: The town that keeps flooding but no-one wants to leave

image.altText: A woman in a shearer's singlet leans against a wooden wall in shearing shed

props.synopsis: After her first day shearing, Mikayla Hall's hands were covered in blisters. Three years later she's one of the fastest female shearers in Australia.

title.children: Speed shearer has come a long way since early days of blisters and bandages

image.altText: Two men wearing blue shirts sitting in a room, smiling.

props.synopsis: Former police officer Russell Reynolds has acted in Hollywood films, but as the curtain rises on the next stage in his life, he's shining a light on how to help at-risk youth.

title.children: From the blue line to the red carpet, retired cop takes a bow

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed with a serious look on his face with th Hard quiz logo in the top left corner

props.synopsis: Back again? I doubt you'll do any better than last week.

title.children: You better believe I’m here to judge you. Let’s play… HARD!
